column8: This use of the commas to seaprate citations and slash to indicate joint authors (I assume) is idiosyncratic. Use semicolon to separate multiple citations. use commas and ampersands to list multiple authors. Change throughout.
use only in parentheses; alternatively, use *such as*
'Each paper should start with a short abstract'
'Small caps are used to draw attention to an important term at its first use or definition'
Should this example be part of the preceding sentence?
should this be *coherence*, or alternatively should you have *cohesion* before the colon?

The first initial is used throughout to refer to author contributions in this volume. In this some instance, it appears motivated by the need to dinstinguish between the two Rysov√°s. Elsewhere, the motivation is unclear.  The style guide says, 'the names of authors and editors should be given in their full form as in the publication, without truncation of given names,' but this is in the references. There appears to be no guidelines specifically for the text.
'Each paper has its own list of references'
Choose a synonym to avoid garden path
This is the first use of Oxford comma, despite many opportunities above. Consider using consistently.
it's unclear what the coordinates are here
What does it mean for complexity to demand resources? Could it be the analysis or resolution of complexity that demands resources?
'data; Kutuzov & Kunilovskaya 2015).' OR 'data in Kutuzov & Kunilovskaya 2015).'
Use ampersand *&* inside parentheses; change throughout
this *to* is the preposition, not the infinitive marker. A COCA search shows the overwhelming majority of verbs are *-ing* form after *key to*.
is there a noun missing here (*lexical items*)? Is *form* a noun and a verb is missing?
*allow* requires an object. *Allow* someone *to inspect*... Alternatively, use *allow for the inspection*
insert a comma. cf. *moreover* in the following paragraph.
*of* requies an NP complement, but only gets AdjP here. Replace *in terms of* with *as*
Her corpus? Her annotations? Her chapter?
The other questions are interrogative main clauses, while this is an interrogative content clause. Change *How* to *What is the best way* or some such.
This is potentially double, which is not allowed.
use *into*, especially given the subsequent *and on*
consider using *that* instead of *which* for the integrated relative clause; alternatively, consider adding a matching comma before *dealt* or removing the one after *book*
an *of* PP is standard here, rather than a *to* infinitive; use *of uncovering*
I would expect this to be coordinated with something like *and continuing with*; consider striking or replacing with *including*
'the most frequent connectives in present-day Czech'
I suggest you this solution: '..suggested by Gries & Deshors (2014).'
Are these texts translated from or into Russian?
'das' doesn't normally mean 'this' (it's not a demonstrative), but just 'the' or 'that'.
reword to clarify whether it is the texts or languages that may vary
There is already a Footnote 2 on the previous page. Not sure how you managed this as LaTeX usually keeps track of footnotes, but you need to sort it out for the entire chapter.
I'm not sure what you try to say, maybe avoid using the bracket, as the footnote is already an interwoven thought

column7: there is no opening bracket to this
I suggest you to change hope'

The standard way to mark a missing part of the quoted text is [...]

'defined very differently in various linguistic approaches'

column7: this parenthesis is not closed anywhere

column8: Should this be a definite NP?
Do you mean 'As regards' instead of 'For'?
Table 2 is too far away. Try to use the [h!] option to make the float appear on the next page for instance.
maybe use 'in different periods for each individual connective'
'daf√ºr' doesn't really mean 'therefore' (otherwise it would be synonymous with 'darum'), but rather something like 'in return', 'in exchange' or 'instead'
'..can give rise to extra processing efforts ...'
I would say 'Would the annotation not be incomplete without them?'
'To this end we employ models that predict..'
Over the last 20 years or so, research in this area..
Make it clear. Is it Figure 2?

This is a strange claim. Of course they are ungrammatical by themselves, but so is every word or couple of words that is not part of a sentence. The star annotation, in my view, only functions with sentences. So you need to show what you argue in a full sentence example. And anyway, I'm not convinced that your claim is correct (if I understand it correctly), as I can easily think of examples where no anaphoric expression is used, e.g.: 'Due to/Because of a depression, Mike had to quit his job.'
.. these deviations, once again we follow Gries & Deshors (2014)...
maybe there is no hyphenation in this line.
use longer dash to mark appositive element
.., which were instrumental in guiding our work into the right direction.
Make it clear. Is it Figure 2 or Section 2?
I would rather call them prepositional phrases

column7: I suggest you to make a complete example
